thread.title: Oregon State Beavers take pride in finish, but once again undone by slow starts
thread.title_full: Oregon State Beavers take pride in finish, but once again undone by slow starts | OregonLive.com

author: Danny Moran | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Oregon State Beavers take pride in finish, but once again undone by slow starts
text:
PULLMAN, Wash. â€“ There was somehow still life in the eyes of Oregon State 's players as they watched the crescendo of Saturday's disaster unfold.
Washington State safety Shalom Luani snuffed out a late charge at an impossible rally when he intercepted Seth Collins and returned the ball 84 yards for a pick-six that gave the Cougars a 52-25 lead.
In the three minutes and 45 seconds that remained, the Beavers had the energy to block a punt, score a touchdown and shrink the margin of defeat to 52-31.
"There's absolutely no quit in them," said Gary Andersen , "and anybody that watched that game can absolutely understand that."
But while Oregon State showed persistent desire while facing down its fourth double-digit loss of the year, that fight emerged only after digging a hole so deep that seemingly no amount of effort could lead the team back to the surface.
After going blow-for-blow in the first halves of contests against more physically imposing Michigan and Stanford teams, the Beavers have been outscored by a combined score of 79-24 in their opening halves over the last two weeks against Arizona and Washington State.
The self-imposed challenges began with the game's first kickoff, which Washington State receiver Tavares Martin Jr. returned into Oregon State territory on a 51-yard dash.
Eight plays later, when Cougars quarterback Luke Falk had time in the pocket to find River Cracraft in the middle of the field for a 3-yard strike, it marked the fourth consecutive game in which the Beavers allowed a touchdown on their opening defensive drive.
"Obviously we've struggled on defense really on the first drive almost every game," Andersen said. "It's where we're at. I don't have anything that's identified to that."
The score gave Washington State its first points on a day when it went on to tally 45 in the first half, the most for the Cougars in a two-quarter span since 1997. By the end of the half, Falk had six touchdown passes and only five incompletions (28 for 33).
The offense also shared responsibility for the lethargic start.
For the third game in a row, Oregon State opened its first offensive series with a three-and-out. In their previous two defeats against Stanford and Arizona, the Beavers mustered nine yards on each of their two respective opening drives before electing to punt on fourth and one.
There was no such momentum generated on the Palouse.
Seth Collins' two-yard quarterback scamper was followed with a loss of two and an incomplete pass. Oregon State punted and Washington State grabbed a 14-0 lead less than three minutes later after a seven-play, 69-yard drive.
After Wednesday's practice, offensive coordinator Dave Baldwin took responsibility for allowing the early deficit against Arizona to alter his play calling and put too much emphasis on the pass.
Andersen said the early struggles on both sides of the ball did not affect the game's play-calling Saturday.
Collins finished with 124 yards on 23 carries, his third game of the season reaching the triple-digit threshold on the ground. Seven different Oregon State players carried the ball for 218 yards, the team's highest rushing yardage mark since its 35-21 win over San Jose State.
"Obviously a week ago we were in a very similar situation," Andersen said. "We were not able to run the ball as effectively against Arizona as we were today. We wanted to stick with that game plan a little bit."
But even the offensive highlight that emerged out of a lost day only came once the Beavers faced an uphill fight.
In the first quarter, Oregon State mustered only 14 yards on eight carries. And it was on the second quarter's second play that Falk lofted a pinpoint 23-yard pass to Gabe Marks, putting Washington State up 21-3.
Before the Beavers' offensive game plan had the opportunity to get moving, the team was down by 18 points.
"You prepare in practice to play good teams like this and when you get to the game, everything you do in practice has to translate," sophomore safety Justin Strong said. "In that first half, that wasn't the case."
The Beavers were also penalized eight times for 61 yards in the first half. Perhaps the most crucial was an offside call before Washington State snapped the ball on third and 15 from the Beavers' 46. The Cougars converted the ensuing third and 10 and capped off the drive with Falk's lob to Marks.
"We've got a ways to go," Andersen said. "So we'll keep battling."
-- Danny Moran
dmoran@oregonian.com
@DannyJMoran
